In these earlier sections of English history our chro- nicler has little to add to the events recorded in authors now extant. In the later portionS, in which he ap- proaches more nearly his own period, his narrative shows many variatione from received authorities, and these will be examined at a future opportunity.

I cannot dismiss these remarks without again express- ing my obligations to Sir Thomas Phillipps for his kindness in allowing me access to his valuable copy of the chronicles‚ and in favouring me with facilities for transcribing and collating it, in repeated visits to his library at Cheltenham.
